elements.content: A series of monochloride-bridged, dinuclear metallacycles of the general formula [M2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L)2]­(ClO4)3 have been prepared using the third-generation, ditopic bis­(pyrazolyl)­methane ligands L = m-bis­[bis­(1-pyrazolyl)­methyl]­benzene (L m ), M = Cu­(II), Zn­(II), and L = m-bis­[bis­(3,5-dimethyl-1-pyrazolyl)­methyl]­benzene (L m *), M = Fe­(II), Co­(II), Ni­(II), Cu­(II), Zn­(II), Cd­(II). These complexes were synthesized from the direct reactions of M­(ClO4)2·6H2O, MCl2, and the ligand, L m or L m *, in the appropriate stoichiometric amounts. Three analogous complexes of the formula [M2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L)2]­(BF4)3, L = L m , M = Cu­(II), and L = L m *, M = Co­(II), Cu­(II), were prepared from the reaction of [M2(μ-F)­(μ-L)2]­(BF4)3 and (CH3)3SiCl. The bromide-bridged complex [Cu2(μ-Br)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3 was prepared by the first method. Three acyclic complexes, [Co2(μ-L m )­μ-Cl4], [Co2(μ-L m *)­Cl4], and [Co2(μ-L m *)­Br4], were also prepared. The structures of all [M2(μ-X)­(μ-L)2]3+ (X = Cl–, Br–) complexes have two ditopic bis­(pyrazolyl)­methane ligands bridging two metals in a metallacyclic arrangement. The fifth coordination site of the distorted trigonal bipyramidal metal centers is filled by a bridging halide ligand that has an unusual linear or nearly linear M–X–M angle. The NMR spectra of [Zn2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3 and especially [Cd2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3 demonstrate that the metallacycle structure is maintained in solution. Solid state magnetic susceptibility data for the copper­(II) compounds show very strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions, with −J values of 536 cm–1 for [Cu2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m )2]­(ClO4)3·xCH3CN, 720 cm–1 for [Cu2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3, and 945 cm–1 for [Cu2(μ-Br)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3·2CH3CN. Smaller but still substantial antiferromagnetic interactions are observed with other first row transition metals, with −J values of 98 cm–1 for [Ni2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3, 55 cm–1 for [Co2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3, and 34 cm–1 for [Fe2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3. EPR spectra of [Cu2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(BF4)3 confirm the d z 2 ground state of copper­(II). In addition, the sign of the zero-field splitting parameter D was determined to be positive for [Cu2(μ-F)­(μ-L m *)2]­(BF4)3. Electronic spectra of the copper­(II) complexes as well as Mössbauer spectra of the iron­(II) complexes were also studied in relation with the EPR spectra and magnetic properties, respectively. Density functional theory calculations were performed using ORCA, and exchange integral values were obtained that parallel but are slightly higher than the experimental values by about 30%.

elements.content: Monochloride- and bromide-bridged, dinuclear metallacycles of the general formula [M2(μ-X)­(μ-L)2]­(ClO4)3 (L = ditopic bis­(1-pyrazolyl)­methyl ligands) have been prepared and structurally characterized. They show very strong antiferromagnetic interactions. EPR spectra have confirmed the d z 2 ground state of trigonal bipyramidal copper­(II), a result supported by DFT calculations. Overall, the antiferromagnetic interactions increase along the series F− < Cl−< OH− < Br−, as the Cu−X−Cu angle increases, and from left to right along the first row transition metals.
elements.clean_text: Monochloride- and bromide-bridged, dinuclear metallacycles of the general formula [M2(μ-X)(μ-L)2](ClO4)3 (L = ditopic bis(1-pyrazolyl)methyl ligands) have been prepared and structurally characterized. They show very strong antiferromagnetic interactions. EPR spectra have confirmed the d z 2  ground state of trigonal bipyramidal copper(II), a result supported by DFT calculations. Overall, the antiferromagnetic interactions increase along the series F- < Cl-< OH- < Br-, as the Cu-X-Cu angle increases, and from left to right along the first row transition metals.

elements.content: Multinuclear complexes of magnetically active metal centers are of current interest. In order to understand the magnetic properties of complicated metallic clusters, scientists must gain fundamental understanding of the magnetic behavior of simpler units. Significant attention has been given to dinuclear systems where the metal centers are directly linked by small anions such as hydroxide, fluoride, chloride, and bromide. With copper­(II) in the dihydroxide-bridged systems, it was shown that the magnitude of the antiferromagnetic superexchange interaction, expressed in terms of J (exchange coupling constant) corresponding to the singlet–triplet energy gap, correlates linearly with the Cu–O–Cu angle. In contrast, similar simple magneto-structural correlations were not found for the chloride- and bromide-bridged compounds, where the singlet–triplet energy gap seems to be dependent on M–Cl­(Br)–M bond angles divided by the longer M–Cl­(Br) bond length. This parameter follows a smooth curve. Uncontrolled variations in the coordination sphere around the metal centers and a limited number of model compounds further complicate the observation of magneto-structural correlations, especially in the case of bromide.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Multinuclear complexes of magnetically active metal centers are of current interest. In order to understand the magnetic properties of complicated metallic clusters, scientists must gain fundamental understanding of the magnetic behavior of simpler units. Significant attention has been given to dinuclear systems where the metal centers are directly linked by small anions such as hydroxide, fluoride, chloride, and bromide. With copper(II) in the dihydroxide-bridged systems, it was shown that the magnitude of the antiferromagnetic superexchange interaction, expressed in terms of J (exchange coupling constant) corresponding to the singlet-triplet energy gap, correlates linearly with the Cu-O-Cu angle. In contrast, similar simple magneto-structural correlations were not found for the chloride- and bromide-bridged compounds, where the singlet-triplet energy gap seems to be dependent on M-Cl(Br)-M bond angles divided by the longer M-Cl(Br) bond length. This parameter follows a smooth curve. Uncontrolled variations in the coordination sphere around the metal centers and a limited number of model compounds further complicate the observation of magneto-structural correlations, especially in the case of bromide.

elements.content: Much of our current efforts are centered around the syntheses of metal complexes with third-generation bis­(pyrazolyl)­methane ligands that control the overall structure of metal complexes by functionalization at the noncoordinating “back” position. An important class of these ligands links two bis­(pyrazolyl)­methane units through a 1,3-substituted arene spacer (). These ligands support the formation of dinuclear metallacycles. When the syntheses are carried out with metals in the 2+ oxidation state, the metallacycles form with small anions bridging the two metals (). This connection establishes a direct communication pathway between the metal centers, leading to antiferromagnetic superexchange interactions for metal systems with unpaired electrons.

elements.content: We are particularly interested in preparing complexes that retain the metallacyclic structure supported by L m or L m * while varying the bridging monoanions, in an effort to gain fundamental understanding of the magnetic properties of these systems. The magnitude of the superexchange within the dinuclear units is altered by modification of the small, bridging anionic groups (X) or the ligand (L m or L m *), which results in changes in the M···M distance and/or M–X–M angle. Changes in this angle may also result in modifications in the geometry around the metal centers: trigonal bipyramidal versus square pyramidal. We have previously reported results for complexes where the bridging group is fluoride or hydroxide, and more recently cyanide and azide. Reported here are our efforts to prepare analogous complexes where the bridge is chloride or bromide. Some of these results have been communicated previously.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

For the synthesis of the metal complexes, standard Schlenk techniques were used. The solvents were not dried prior to use unless otherwise mentioned. The ligands, L   m    and L   m  *, were prepared following reported procedures. The complexes [Co2(μ-F)(μ-L   m  *)2](BF4)3, [Cu2(μ-F)(μ-L   m  *)2](BF4)3, [Cu2(μ-F)(μ-L   m  )2](BF4)3, and [Fe2(μ-F)(μ-L   m  *)2](BF4)3 (16) were prepared as reported previously. All other chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich or Strem Chemicals and used as received.

elements.content: Crystals used for elemental analysis and mass spectrometry were removed from the mother liquor, rinsed with diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum, a process that removes solvent of crystallization, if present. Elemental analyses were performed on vacuum-dried samples by Robertson Microlit Laboratories (Ledgewood, NJ). Mass spectrometric measurements were obtained on a MicroMass QTOF spectrometer in an acid-free environment.

elements.content: 1H, 13C, and 113Cd NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Mercury/VX 300, Varian Mercury/VX 400, or Varian INOVA 500 spectrometer. All chemical shifts are in ppm and were referenced to residual undeuterated solvent signals (1H), to deuterated solvent signals (13C), or externally to CdCl2 (113Cd).

elements.content: High-field, high-frequency EPR spectra at temperatures ranging from ca. 6 to 290 K were recorded on a home-built spectrometer at the EMR facility of the NHMFL. The instrument is a transmission-type device in which microwaves are propagated in cylindrical lightpipes. The microwaves were generated by a phase-locked Virginia Diodes source generating frequency of 13 ± 1 GHz and producing its harmonics of which the 2nd, 4th, 6th, 8th, 16th, 24th, and 32nd were available. A superconducting magnet (Oxford Instruments) capable of reaching a field of 17 T was employed. The powder samples were not constrained and showed no magnetic torqueing at high magnetic fields.

elements.content: Field- and temperature-dependent 57Fe nuclear gamma (γ) resonance (Mössbauer) spectra were recorded using a spectrometer operated in constant acceleration mode that was fitted with a liquid helium cooled Janis 8DT Super Varitemp cryostat and an 8 T American Magnetics superconducting magnet. This setup allowed the application of magnetic fields parallel to the propagation direction of the γ radiation. The light source consisted of 100 mCi 57Co dispersed in a rhodium foil. The isomer shift values are reported against the centroid of a α-Fe spectrum recorded at room temperature (RT). The absorbers used during this investigation were obtained by dispersing ∼30 mg of the compounds, prepared using natural abundance iron, in Nujol mineral oil and contained in custom-made polyethylene absorbers.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility measurements over the temperature range 1.8–300 K were performed at a magnetic field of 0.5 T using a Quantum Design SQUID MPMSXL-5 magnetometer. Correction for the sample holder, as well as the diamagnetic correction χD, estimated from the Pascal constants, was applied.

The iron­(II) compounds, Fe­(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.183 g, 0.504 mmol) and FeCl2 (0.022 g, 0.17 mmol), were dissolved in 4 mL of methanol. Separately, L m * (0.324 g, 0.672 mmol) was dissolved in 12 mL of methanol and was transferred by cannula into the iron­(II) solution. The reaction mixture was stirred for 5 h, after which time the system was filtered by cannula; the remaining solid was washed with Et2O (10 mL) and dried under vacuum overnight, affording 0.200 g (42%) of the crude product. Single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray and other studies were grown by the vapor diffusion of Et2O into 1 mL of acetonitrile solutions of the crude solid. Anal. Calcd (Found) for C56H68Cl4­Fe2N16O12: C, 47.68 (47.98); H, 4.86 (4.88); N, 15.89 (16.27). MS ESI­(+) m/z (rel % abund) [assgn]: 1311 (2) [Fe2(L m *)2­Cl­(ClO4)2]+, 605 (38) [Fe2(L m *)2Cl­(ClO4)]2+, 483 (30) [L m * + H]+, 370 (100) [Fe2(L m *)2Cl]3+.

elements.content: Under N2, [Co2(μ-F)­(μ-L m *)2]­(BF4)3 (0.166 g, 0.121 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of dry acetonitrile and cooled to 0 °C for 30 min. Solid (CH3)3SiCl (0.013 g, 0.12 mmol) was added all at once to the cobalt­(II) solution. The solution immediately changed color from pink to blue. The reaction flask was removed from the cooling bath, allowed to warm to room temperature, and stirred for 12 h. The solvent was removed by rotary evaporation, and the product was recrystallized by vapor diffusion of Et2O into 1 mL acetonitrile solutions of the blue solid. The resulting pink crystals were identified as 3, 0.050 g (30%). Anal. Calcd (Found) for C56H68Cl­Co2N16B3F12: C, 48.78 (48.20); H, 4.97 (4.57); N, 16.25 (16.17). The methanolic solution of the ligand, L   m   (0.185 g, 0.500 mmol), was transferred by cannula to the solution of CoCl2⋅6H2O (0.238 g, 1.00 mmol) in methanol to yield 0.205 g (65%) of blue precipitate. Single crystals of 5 were isolated upon slow evaporation of an acetonitrile/N,N-dimethylformamide solution of the blue precipitate at 5 °C. Anal. Calcd (Found) for C20H18Co2N8Cl4: C, 38.12 (38.40); H, 2.88 (3.07); N, 17.78 (17.50). Crystals of 5 were first isolated from a similar reaction to the synthesis of 2 using L   m   followed by recrystallization of the precipitate from methanol.

elements.content: Compound 6 was prepared similarly to compound 1 starting from Ni­(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.184 g, 0.504 mmol) and NiCl2·6H2O (0.040 g, 0.17 mmol). The reaction afforded 0.160 g (33%) of a green solid. An additional 0.165 g (35%) of 6 can be isolated from the mother liquor by rotary evaporation of the solvent. Single crystals suitable for X-ray studies were grown by the vapor diffusion of Et2O into highly diluted 1 mL acetonitrile solutions of 6. Anal. elements.content: The copper­(II) salts, Cu­(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.187 g, 0.504 mmol) and CuBr2 (0.038 g, 0.168 mmol), were dissolved in 4 mL of MeOH. The ligand, L m * (0.324 g, 0.672 mmol), dissolved in 10 mL of MeOH, was transferred by cannula into the copper­(II) salt solution. A dark green precipitate formed instantly. The reaction mixture was stirred for 5 h, after which time the system was filtered by cannula, washed with 5 mL ether, and dried in vacuum overnight, affording 0.335 g (68%) of the crude product. Single crystals suitable for X-ray and other studies were grown by layering Et2O on top of a concentrated acetonitrile solution of this solid and a buffer layer of pure acetonitrile; crystals of 14·2CH3CN formed. Anal. Calcd (Found) for C56H68Cl3Br­Cu2N16O12: C, 45.74 (45.57); H, 4.66 (4.63); N, 15.24 (15.39). MS ESI­(+) m/z (rel % abund) [assgn]: 1371 (3) [Cu2(L m *)2­(Br)­(ClO4)2]+, 1108 (2) [Cu­(L m *)2Br]+, 635 (25) [Cu2(L m *)2­Br­(ClO4)]2+, 545 (100) [Cu­(L m *)]+, 514 (50) [Cu­(L m *)2]2+, 483 (65) [L m * + H]+, 390 (52) [Cu2(L m *)2Br]3+.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction intensity data for compounds 1–15 were measured on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). Raw area detector data frame processing was performed with the SAINT+ and SADABS programs. Final unit cell parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of large sets of strong reflections taken from each data set. Direct methods structure solutions, difference Fourier calculations, and full-matrix least-squares refinements against F 2 were performed using SHELXS and SHELXL, implemented in OLEX2. Non-hydrogen atoms were in general refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, the exception being disordered species, which were refined isotropically. Prevalent anion and solvent disorder was modeled with the aid of 1,2 and 1,3 distance restraints, or with a disorder component restrained to adopt a similar geometry as an ordered anion in the structure (SHELX SAME instructions). Hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. Details of the data collections and refinements are given in Tables S1–S4 in Supporting Information.

Crystallographic Studies

X-ray diffraction intensity data for compounds 1-15 were measured on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). Raw area detector data frame processing was performed with the SAINT+ and SADABS programs. Final unit cell parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of large sets of strong reflections taken from each data set. Direct methods structure solutions, difference Fourier calculations, and full-matrix least-squares refinements against F 2 were performed using SHELXS and SHELXL, implemented in OLEX2. Non-hydrogen atoms were in general refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, the exception being disordered species, which were refined isotropically. Prevalent anion and solvent disorder was modeled with the aid of 1,2 and 1,3 distance restraints, or with a disorder component restrained to adopt a similar geometry as an ordered anion in the structure (SHELX SAME instructions). Hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. Details of the data collections and refinements are given in Tables S1-S4 in Supporting Information.

elements.content: During preliminary examinations at different temperatures, compounds 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, and 8 were observed to undergo a phase transition. The phase change is signaled by the appearance of additional peaks in the diffraction pattern when the crystals are cooled, and is accompanied by enlargement of the unit cell. The transitions are of the order–disorder type, caused by ordering of the anions at lower temperatures. All transitions occur without a change in crystal system (triclinic) or loss of space group symmetry. The space group P1̅ is retained throughout the transition as the symmetry group of both the high- and low-temperature forms. The transitions are therefore a special case of the klassengleiche-type transition with an isomorphic subgroup, and do not require the occurrence of twinning. Other details of the crystallography are in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: The monochloride-bridged dinuclear metallacycles were synthesized from the direct reactions of the building blocks, M­(ClO4)2·6H2O, MCl2, and the ligand, L m or L m *, according to the equation below.Similar assemblies were isolated for copper­(II) by exchange reactions of the corresponding fluoride-bridged metallacycle with (CH3)3SiCl, as shown below. The precursors were synthesized according to reported procedures. These reactions result in the BF4 – rather than the ClO4 – derivatives of the chloride-bridged metallacycles.This (CH3)3SiCl reaction with [Co2(μ-F)­(μ-L m *)2]­(BF4)3 yielded two different species, the metallacycle 3, which was isolated in significantly lower yield than the copper­(II) species 8, and [Co2(μ-L m *)­Cl4] (4), a different type of dinuclear compound where the metal centers are bridged by only one ligand (vide infra), and the charge neutrality is achieved by coordination of additional chloride ions. The analogous complex of the unsubstituted ligand, [Co2(μ-L m )­(μ-Cl)4] (5), was first isolated from the reaction of Co­(ClO4)2·6H2O, CoCl2·6H2O, and L m using the stoichiometry of the first reaction, and was subsequently synthesized by the stoichiometric reaction of CoCl2·6H2O and L m in better yield.
elements.clean_text:
Results

Synthesis

The monochloride-bridged dinuclear metallacycles were synthesized from the direct reactions of the building blocks, M(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, MCl2, and the ligand, L   m   or L   m  *, according to the equation below.Similar assemblies were isolated for copper(II) by exchange reactions of the corresponding fluoride-bridged metallacycle with (CH3)3SiCl, as shown below. The precursors were synthesized according to reported procedures. These reactions result in the BF4 - rather than the ClO4 - derivatives of the chloride-bridged metallacycles.This (CH3)3SiCl reaction with [Co2(μ-F)(μ-L   m  *)2](BF4)3 yielded two different species, the metallacycle 3, which was isolated in significantly lower yield than the copper(II) species 8, and [Co2(μ-L   m  *)Cl4] (4), a different type of dinuclear compound where the metal centers are bridged by only one ligand (vide infra), and the charge neutrality is achieved by coordination of additional chloride ions. The analogous complex of the unsubstituted ligand, [Co2(μ-L   m  )(μ-Cl)4] (5), was first isolated from the reaction of Co(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, CoCl2⋅6H2O, and L   m   using the stoichiometry of the first reaction, and was subsequently synthesized by the stoichiometric reaction of CoCl2⋅6H2O and L   m   in better yield.

elements.content: The bromide-bridged copper­(II) metallacycle, 14, was synthesized similarly to the analogous chloride-bridged compounds directly from the reaction of the appropriate building blocks. The reaction of [Co2(μ-F)­(μ-L m *)2]­(BF4)3 and (CH3)3SiBr resulted in [Co2(μ-L m *)­Br4] (15).

elements.content: Positive-ion electrospray mass spectra (ESI+-MS) of all the metallacyclic species are similar. For [M2(μ-X)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3, X = Cl– or Br– (1, 2, 6, 7, 11, 13, and 14), clusters such as [M2(L m *)2X­(ClO4)2]+, [M2(L m *)2X­(ClO4)]2+, and [M2(L m *)2X]3+ were observed in all spectra. The ESI+-MS spectra of 3 and 8 show similar peaks with the corresponding BF4 – counterions. In several cases (1, 2, 6, 13) the base peak in the spectrum is [M2(L m *)2Cl]3+; for the copper­(II) compounds, it also has relatively high intensity, but the base peak is [Cu­(L m *)]+. For compound 12, the base peak is [Zn­(L m )2]2+. These data indicate that the metallacycles are highly stable even in the gas phase, especially the L m * compounds. These observations are in good agreement with the structures determined in the solid state and for 11 and 13 in solution.
elements.clean_text:
Mass Spectrometry

Positive-ion electrospray mass spectra (ESI+-MS) of all the metallacyclic species are similar. For [M2(μ-X)(μ-L   m  *)2](ClO4)3, X = Cl- or Br- (1, 2, 6, 7, 11, 13, and 14), clusters such as [M2(L   m  *)2X(ClO4)2]+, [M2(L   m  *)2X(ClO4)]2+, and [M2(L   m  *)2X]3+ were observed in all spectra. The ESI+-MS spectra of 3 and 8 show similar peaks with the corresponding BF4 - counterions. In several cases (1, 2, 6, 13) the base peak in the spectrum is [M2(L   m  *)2Cl]3+; for the copper(II) compounds, it also has relatively high intensity, but the base peak is [Cu(L   m  *)]+. For compound 12, the base peak is [Zn(L   m  )2]2+. These data indicate that the metallacycles are highly stable even in the gas phase, especially the L   m  * compounds. These observations are in good agreement with the structures determined in the solid state and for 11 and 13 in solution.

elements.content: The overall structures of the other [M2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L)2]3+ complexes, L = L m or L m *, are very similar (see Supporting Information for additional structural drawings and information). In all of these metallacyclic structures, ligand L adopts a syn-conformation, and the geometry around the metal centers is highly distorted trigonal bipyramidal. The equatorial (e) angles are distorted from the ideal values, e.g., [Co2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3 (2) at 295 K: ee-N–Co–N 102.82(9)°; ee-N–Co–Cl 126.04­(6)°, 131.14(7)°. Similarly, the atoms in the axial (a) positions form distorted angles, e.g., 2 at 295 K: aa-N–Co-N 172.80(8)°; ae-N–Co–N 86.34(9)–97.92(9)°; ae–N–Co-Cl 86.01(6)°, 86.81(6)°. For most metals, the equatorial bond lengths are shorter than the axial bond lengths, e.g., 2 at 295 K: e-N–Co 2.050(2) and 2.053(2) Å; a-N–Co 2.103­(2) and 2.119(2) Å. This trend is reversed in the case of the copper­(II) compounds as a result of pseudo-Jahn–Teller distortion, e.g., [Cu2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3 (7) at 295 K: e-Cu–N 2.088(3) and 2.099(3)­Å; a-Cu–N 1.984­(3) and 1.993(2) Å. In addition, the τ5 values, 0.58–0.83, summarized in , support the trigonal bipyramidal geometry around the metal centers (τ5 > 0.5) with various degrees of distortion toward a square pyramidal geometry.

elements.content: In most metallacycles, the M–Cl–M angles () are linear or nearly linear, 168–180°. One notable exception is one of the forms of [Cu2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m )2]­(ClO4)3·1.5CH3CN (9·1.5CH3CN) where the angle drops to 138.53(13)°, with the other form in that structure at 167.79(7)°. The angles are also consistently lower in the two different lattice solvates of [Cd2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3, 158.01(10)–167.73(16)°, where the metal has a much larger ionic radius than in the other structures.

elements.content: The order/disorder-type phase change for 1–3 and 6–8 does not result in significant structural modifications. The induced changes upon cooling of the samples are not bigger than ±3° for the N–M–N and N–M–Cl bond angles and ±0.02 Å for the a-M–N, ±0.05 Å for the e-M–N, and ±0.02 Å for the M–Cl bond lengths. These small changes in the crystal structures induce a dramatic color change in [Co2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3 (2) upon change in the temperature from 295 K (red/purple crystals) to 100 K (green crystals), Figure S4. Also, counteranion changes from ClO4 – to BF4 – result in only small differences of ±0.02 Å in the M–Cl bond lengths, as demonstrated by the copper­(II) compounds 7 and 8 with L m * and 9·1.5CH3CN, 9·2CH3CN, and 10·3CH3CN with L m ().

elements.content: The structure of the bromide-bridged compound [Cu2(μ-Br)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3·2CH3CN (14·2CH3CN), , is similar to the chloride-bridged analogue, 7; the geometry around the metal centers is still distorted trigonal bipyramidal, τ5 > 0.64. Change of the chloride to bromide bridge results in a larger Cu···Cu nonbonding distance, 4.66 Å versus 4.95 Å, while the linearity of the bridge is retained; Cu–Br–Cu angle is 180°.

Change of the chloride to bromide bridge results in a larger Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu nonbonding distance, 4.66 Å versus 4.95 Å, while the linearity of the bridge is retained; Cu-Br-Cu angle is 180°.

elements.content: In the acyclic structure of [Co2(μ-L m *)­Cl4] (4) and analogous [Co2(μ-L m *)­Br4] (15), the ligand, L m *, adopts an anti-conformation; the two bis­(pyrazolyl)­methane units point toward opposite sides of the plane defined by the phenylene spacer, and chelates two cobalt­(II) centers (). Further, coordination of two chloride or bromide ions to each cobalt­(II) results in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment around the metal centers, with, for 4, N–Co–N angles 91.96(9)° and 92.78(10)°, N–Co–Cl angles between 107.08° and 118.38°, and Cl–Co–Cl angles 109.74(3)° and 112.23(3)°. Compound 15 is analogous to 4, with N–Co–N angles 92.4(2)° and 93.1(2)°, N–Co–Br angles between 107.69° and 118.83°, and Br–Co–Br angles 108.82(4)° and 111.55(4)°.

elements.content: Similar to dinuclear Co2(μ-L m *)­Cl4 (4), in the structure of polymeric [Co2(μ-L m )­Cl4] (5) the ligand, L m , is in an anti-conformation bridging two cobalt­(II) centers. One of the two chlorides (Cl1, Cl2), terminal in compound 4, further bridges two cobalt­(II) centers to generate the polymeric chain (). The coordination number around cobalt­(II) increases from four to five, resulting in a trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The τ5 values are 0.90 (Co1) and 0.72 (Co2). The parallel polymeric chains participate in weak intra- and interchain CH···Cl interactions (C–H···Cl 2.599(2) Å (172.37°) and 2.453(2) Å (165.31°), respectively), Figure S12.

elements.content: In the 1H NMR spectra of [Zn2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]-(ClO4)3 (11) and [Cd2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3 (13), , only one set of resonances can be observed for the m-phenylene spacers (e, f, g) and the methine (d) hydrogens. In contrast, the pyrazolyl methyl groups (a* and c*) and the pyrazolyl b hydrogens show two equal intensity resonances for each position, indicating two sets of nonequivalent pyrazolyl rings (c* 11, 2.59/2.39 ppm; 13, 2.54/2.44 ppm; a* 11, 1.76/1.29 ppm; 13, 1.98/1.67 ppm; b 11, 6.29/6.08 ppm; 13, 6.32/6.12 ppm). As reported previously with the F–- and OH–-bridged analogues, we can assign the more shielded methyl resonance pair to the 3 (a*)-position methyl groups because in the solid state structures the axial 3-methyl pyrazolyl groups point toward the phenylene spacers causing the shielding. The 1H NMR spectra of [Zn2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m )2]­(ClO4)3 (12) show severe line width broadening; even at −40 °C, assignment of the resonances was not possible.

In contrast, the pyrazolyl methyl groups (a* and c*) and the pyrazolyl b hydrogens show two equal intensity resonances for each position, indicating two sets of nonequivalent pyrazolyl rings (c* 11, 2.59/2.39 ppm; 13, 2.54/2.44 ppm; a* 11, 1.76/1.29 ppm; 13, 1.98/1.67 ppm; b 11, 6.29/6.08 ppm; 13, 6.32/6.12 ppm). As reported previously with the F-- and OH--bridged analogues, we can assign the more shielded methyl resonance pair to the 3 (a*)-position methyl groups because in the solid state structures the axial 3-methyl pyrazolyl groups point toward the phenylene spacers causing the shielding. The 1H NMR spectra of [Zn2(μ-Cl)(μ-L   m  )2](ClO4)3 (12) show severe line width broadening; even at -40 °C, assignment of the resonances was not possible.

elements.content: Similar to the 1H NMR results, in the 13C NMR spectra of 11 and 13 there is one set of resonances for each type of carbon atom of the linking groups, but two sets of resonances are observed for the 3,5-dimethylpyrazolyl carbons. For these pyrazolyl resonances in the spectra of compound 13, cadmium­(II) satellites were observed with J C–Cd between 5 and 7 Hz. The 113Cd NMR spectrum of 13 shows a single relatively broad resonance at 133.4 ppm.

elements.content: The results above indicate that the dinuclear structures shown in the solid state are retained in acetonitrile for both 11 and 13. The solid state structures predict that if similar [M2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]3+, M = Zn­(II) or Cd­(II), cationic units are present in solution, two pairs of resonances should be observed for each hydrogen and carbon of the pyrazolyl rings: one set for those oriented along the M–Cl–M axis, equatorial (, blue), and another set for those perpendicular to it, axial (red) pyrazolyl rings of the trigonal bipyramidal geometry. In contrast, each type of hydrogen and carbon atom in the m-phenylene spacers and the methine group should be equivalent, again as observed in the solid state. Similar solid and solution structures are also supported by the observation of one more shielded 3-position methyl resonance.

elements.content: The exchange interaction in a dinuclear complex of ions with local spins S 1 and S 2 can be described by the Heisenberg–Dirac–van Vleck Hamiltonian: Ĥ = − J Ŝ 1 Ŝ 2 In this notation, negative J denotes antiferromagnetic interaction, and |J| is the separation between the coupled-spin states S = 0 and S = 1. The energies of the coupled states with spin S in the range |S 1 – S 2| to S 1 + S 2 follow Lande’s interval rule as shown in .

elements.content: Dinuclear compounds almost always contain a small fraction (f) of monomeric impurities. The total susceptibility thus is χ = ( 1 − f ) χ d + 2 f χ monomer where χ monomer = ( N g 2 μ B 2 / 3 k T ) · S ( S + 1 ) with S = 1/2 in the copper­(II) case.

elements.content: Because of the observed very strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions, the magnetic susceptibilities of the Cl–- and Br–-bridged copper­(II) complexes at low temperatures are dominated by the monomeric impurities. In , we present only the dimer contribution that was calculated from the experimental data using χ d = ( χ − 2 f χ monomer ) / ( 1 − f ) The experimental susceptibilities shown in were obtained by choosing f manually so that the low-temperature χd becomes constant. If that constant was not zero, the deviation was interpreted so as to be due to imperfect Pascal constant and was subtracted from the data. This approach is justified as a small inaccuracy in the Pascal contribution has a very large influence on the very low-temperature susceptibilities of these compounds. The f values of 0.0047, 0.015, and 0.02 were obtained for 7, 9, and 14, respectively. The χd data obtained in this way were fitted. For all three compounds, the magnetic susceptibility decreases with temperature, and below 100 K is close to 0. Data fitted in the standard way result in similar −J values.

CuFCu = [Cu2(μ-F)­(μ-L m *)2]­(BF4)3 (17).

For the magnetic measurements on compound 9, a mixture of two lattice solvates was used as both 9·1.5CH3CN and 9·2CH3CN are isolated from the same crystallization tube (see above) in an approximately 95% to 5% ratio. The 9·1.5CH3CN form containing two independent, equally observed cations (Cu–Cl–Cu 138.53° and 167.79°) dominates the sample. These angles are significantly smaller than those in the analogous system using the L m * ligand, 7, where the angle is 180°, as it is for all copper­(II) complexes with this ligand. The antiferromagnetic interaction is stronger in the linear L m * system than in the bent L m system, −J = 720 cm–1 versus −J = 536 cm–1.

elements.content: A different approach for the magnetic data analysis had to be used for our Fe­(II), Ni­(II), and Co­(II) complexes (). Very large zero-field splitting of the magnetic states in these systems causes deviations from the Lande’s interval rule (), and strongly affects the magnetic susceptibility. The electronic spin Hamiltonian was thus used in the form Ĥ e = − J 12 Ŝ 1 · Ŝ 2 + ∑ i = 1 , 2 ( μ B g i B⃗ · Ŝ i + D i ( Ŝ z , i 2 − 1 3 S i ( S i + 1 ) ) + E i ( Ŝ x , i 2 − Ŝ y , i 2 ) ) where the Di and E i parameters represent the zero-field splitting on individual ions 1 and 2.

elements.content: The energy levels were calculated by full diagonalization of Hamiltonian (), and the magnetic susceptibility was expressed as χ d = − N B ∑ i ∂ E i ∂ B exp ( − E i / k T ) ∑ i exp ( − E i / k T ) + 2 T I P where the summation runs over all |S, M S ⟩ states in a dinuclear system. The derivatives δEi /δB were calculated numerically, by evaluating energies Ei 5 G below and 5 G above the magnetic field of the SQUID instrument (5000 G). As in other dinuclear complexes, a contribution to magnetic susceptibility due to mononuclear impurities was observed, which was taken into account when fitting experimental data. The large zero-field splitting effect is most strikingly reflected in the peculiar magnetic susceptibility of the F–-bridged iron complex 16 (). This effect is caused by strong deviation of the energy levels from Lande’s interval rule; for example, for [Fe2(μ-F)­(μ-L m *)2]­(BF4)3 (16) with J = −16 cm–1 and D 1 = D 2 = −10 cm–1, the energy difference between the |S, M S ⟩ states |1, 0⟩ and |0, 0⟩ is only ∼2.7 cm–1 (see also the Mössbauer section below), while in the absence of zero-field splitting it would be equal to 16 cm–1.

elements.content: In this work, EPR spectra were observed only for the copper­(II) complexes; we have never been able to observe HF EPR or standard EPR spectra of the cobalt­(II) or nickel­(II) compounds. The F–-bridged analogue 16 of the iron­(II) compound 1 produced HF EPR spectra at low temperatures, as did an F–-bridged manganese­(II) complex. Larger exchange interaction in Cl–-bridged 1 prevented spectral observation at very low temperatures due to depopulation of the magnetic states, while (presumably) relaxation effects must have played a role at higher temperatures. In the dinuclear complexes of many-electron ions, a major contribution to the zero-field splitting in the coupled-spin states is related to the zero-field splitting on the monomeric fragments. The coefficient to calculate the D Fe (of ) contribution to D S=1 (of the “giant spin Hamiltonian 8) is −4.2, while for D Co and D Ni we have −2.4 and −1, respectively. Therefore, in our dinuclear systems, enormous triplet state D parameters are expected, –130, –56, and +42 cm –1 for the Co2+, Ni2+, and Fe2+ cases, respectively. Zero-field splitting in higher coupled-spin states is expected to be smaller, and HF EPR was observed in the S = 3 state of 16. In the Co2+ and Ni2+ cases, as well as in the Fe2+ complex 1, the higher excited states are too high in energy, due to larger −J values. It should also be emphasized that even if the microwave quantum energy were sufficient, the intermultiplet transitions (like from S = 0 to S = 1) have very low probability in centrosymmetric bimetallic systems.
elements.clean_text:
EPR

In this work, EPR spectra were observed only for the copper(II) complexes; we have never been able to observe HF EPR or standard EPR spectra of the cobalt(II) or nickel(II) compounds. The F--bridged analogue 16 of the iron(II) compound 1 produced HF EPR spectra at low temperatures, as did an F--bridged manganese(II) complex. Larger exchange interaction in Cl--bridged 1 prevented spectral observation at very low temperatures due to depopulation of the magnetic states, while (presumably) relaxation effects must have played a role at higher temperatures. In the dinuclear complexes of many-electron ions, a major contribution to the zero-field splitting in the coupled-spin states is related to the zero-field splitting on the monomeric fragments. The coefficient to calculate the D Fe (of ) contribution to D  S=1 (of the "giant spin Hamiltonian 8) is -4.2, while for D Co and D Ni we have -2.4 and -1, respectively. Therefore, in our dinuclear systems, enormous triplet state D parameters are expected, -130, -56, and +42 cm -1 for the Co2+, Ni2+, and Fe2+ cases, respectively. Zero-field splitting in higher coupled-spin states is expected to be smaller, and HF EPR was observed in the S = 3 state of 16. In the Co2+ and Ni2+ cases, as well as in the Fe2+ complex 1, the higher excited states are too high in energy, due to larger -J values. It should also be emphasized that even if the microwave quantum energy were sufficient, the intermultiplet transitions (like from S = 0 to S = 1) have very low probability in centrosymmetric bimetallic systems.

elements.content: The copper­(II) complexes reported here exhibited the triplet state (S = 1) spectra, shown in and Figure S13, which were interpreted using the “giant spin” Hamiltonian for S = 1: Ĥ = μ B B · { g } · Ŝ + D { Ŝ z 2 − S ( S + 1 ) / 3 } + E ( Ŝ x 2 − Ŝ y 2 ) The g, D, and E parameters () were found from the simultaneous fitting of the resonances in spectra recorded at various frequencies. An example of such fitting is shown in Figure S14.

elements.content: A striking difference between the spin Hamiltonian parameters of the Cl–-bridged linear systems and those of the F–-bridged species (last column in above) is that the Cl–-bridged ones are much more “axial”, meaning that g x is more similar to g y and the E/D ratio is smaller.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Spectra of Copper(II) Complexes and the Pattern of g Values

A striking difference between the spin Hamiltonian parameters of the Cl--bridged linear systems and those of the F--bridged species (last column in  above) is that the Cl--bridged ones are much more "axial", meaning that g  x  is more similar to g  y  and the E/D ratio is smaller.

elements.content: The molecular orbitals for the ground state and the excited states involving the d xz and d yz copper­(II) orbitals can be expressed as Ψ ( z 2 ) = α d z 2 − α ′ ∑ i a i ϕ ( L i ) Ψ ( y z ) = βd yz − β ′ ∑ i b i ϱ ( L i ) Ψ ( x z ) = γd xz − γ ′ ∑ i c i χ ( L i ) where ϕ­(L i ), ρ­(L i ), and χ­(L i ) represent the appropriate ligand orbitals whose exact form is not important now. The energy and/or delocalization of the d x 2– y 2 and d xy orbitals does not affect the g values because there are no nonzero matrix elements of the L operator between d z 2 and these orbitals. The matrix elements ⟨d xz |L̂ y |d z 2 ⟩ and ⟨d xz |L̂ x |d z 2 ⟩ equal −i√3 and i√3, respectively, and application of classical methods leads to the following equations for the g components g x = 2.0023 − 6 λ α 2 β 2 Δ E ( d z 2 , d y z ) g y = 2.0023 − 6 λ α 2 γ 2 Δ E ( d z 2 , d x z ) g z = 2.0023 where λ = −828 cm–1 is the free-ion spin–orbit coupling constant for Cu2+. The products α2β2 and α2γ2 represent the reduction of the free-ion λ value caused by the covalence, and designations like k x 2 and k y 2 are often used instead, or k ⊥ 2, if k x is expected to be similar to k y . The g z = 2 value should be observed perpendicularly to the trigonal plane. In mononuclear complexes [Cu­(bipy)2X]+ (X = Cl–, I–, N–), with copper­(II) coordination similar to ours, the g z = 2 value was indeed observed in single-crystal EPR perpendicular to the NNX plane with the intermediate (g x ) and the largest (g y ) components along the Cu–X direction and perpendicular to Cu–X in the NNX plane, respectively. It should be emphasized that the largest g component, g y , depends on the energy and delocalization of the d xz orbital, the one directed toward the bridging atom. Therefore, the replacement of the bridging ion F– by Cl– should strongly affect g y , which is indeed observed. The Br–-bridged complex has to be excluded from this discussion as its EPR spectra were observed only at the Q-band frequency, and owing to their low quality, the g values are much less accurate than in the Cl–- and F–-bridged complexes.

elements.content: To obtain a better insight into these issues, the electronic spectra of the copper­(II) complexes were recorded. Very broad and poorly resolved bands were observed in the d–d transition range in both reflectance (solid, 6000–19000 cm–1) and absorbance (solution, 7000–17000 cm–1) spectra. A “filtering” procedure was applied to find the positions of the four expected transitions (see SI for details). Table S5 shows the peak positions in the reflectance spectra found in this way.

Very broad and poorly resolved bands were observed in the d-d transition range in both reflectance (solid, 6000-19000 cm-1) and absorbance (solution, 7000-17000 cm-1) spectra. A "filtering" procedure was applied to find the positions of the four expected transitions (see SI for details). Table S5 shows the peak positions in the reflectance spectra found in this way.

elements.content: For Cu2+ in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment, the orbital energy sequence d z 2 > d x 2– y 2 > d xy > d xz > d yz is typically expected. However, in monomeric systems with Cu2+ coordination similar to ours, the sequence d z 2 > d xz > d xy > d x 2– y 2 > d yz was established. With the g y values observed for our F–- and Cl–-bridged compounds, it is clear that only the lowest-energy band at 8650 cm–1 (F) and 8800 cm–1 (Cl) can be assigned to the d xz –d z 2 transition. When using this assignment, the expression 6λ/ΔE(d z 2 , d xz ) equals 0.57 and 0.56 for the F–- and Cl–-bridged complexes, respectively. The DFT calculations reveal that the unpaired electron density on the copper­(II) d z 2 orbital is 0.67 and 0.63, respectively. That density is represented by α2 in above. Thus, 6λα2/ΔE(d z 2 , d xz ) evaluates to 0.38 and 0.35, respectively, and these numbers represent the maximum deviation of g y , Δg y = g y – 2.0023, if the excited d xz orbital were not delocalized (γ = 1). Since the observed Δg y is 0.33 and 0.25 in the F– and Cl– cases, we can conclude that γ2 equals 0.87 and 0.71, respectively. Assigning any other electronic band (Table S5 and Figures S15 and S16) to the d xz –d z 2 transition results in 6λα2/ΔE(d z 2 , d xz ) being smaller than Δg y measured in the F–-bridged complex (implying γ2 > 1). The lower g y in the Cl– complex compared to F– thus seems to be caused by the increased covalence of the d xz orbital in the former (note that the d xz −d z 2 band position does not change much, Table S5) . In the complex [Cu­(bipy)2Cl]­PF6, the electronic band at ∼12000 cm–1 was assigned to the (d yz,, d xz )−d z 2 transitions. However, the g y component was much smaller than that in our F–- and Cl–-bridged compounds, and k ⊥ = 0.75 was reported for [Cu­(bipy)2Cl]­PF6. From our data, we get k y of 0.76 and 0.67 for the F–- and Cl–-bridged species, respectively. The d yz −d z 2 transition cannot be easily assigned to one of the remaining electronic bands, and due to the poor electronic spectra resolution and inherent uncertainty of the filtering procedure, it is better not to overinterpret the magnitude of g x . Still, the d yz −d z 2 transition is best assigned to the highest-energy band as in Table S5, since other assignments result in β2 coefficients that are too low, particularly for the F–-bridged complex (β2 = 0.6). This EPR-aided interpretation of the electronic spectra leads to the orbital energy sequence d z 2 > d xz > (d x 2– y 2 , d xy ) > d yz . Note that energies of d xy and d x 2– y 2 do not affect the EPR parameters. A dominant feature, particularly well seen in the solution spectra, is a strong band at 27000, 26000, and 25000 cm–1 in the [Cu2(μ-X)­(μ-L m )2]3+ complexes with the F–, Cl–, and Br– bridges, respectively (Figure S15). Strong bands in this general range have been observed in various dinuclear copper­(II) complexes, while they are missing from the spectra of the corresponding monomeric species. These bands are thought to be due to the bridging ligand π to copper­(II) charge transfer transitions.

elements.content: The positions of the resonance lines in EPR do not depend on the signs of the spin Hamiltonian parameters. However, the sign of D affects the intensity pattern in high-field EPR spectra at low temperatures. Using the intensity pattern to determine the sign of D in the antiferromagnetic dinuclear complexes is difficult; the overall spectra intensity decays to zero before the D effect can be seen in the powder spectra. Fortunately, single-crystal high-field EPR sometimes offers a solution. In this work, a 30 mg single crystal of [Cu2(μ-F)­(μ-L m *)2]­(BF4)3 (17) was grown and oriented in the HF EPR instrument with the y axis of the zfs tensor close to the direction of the magnetic field. The EPR spectra of sufficient quality could be recorded at 70 K with the microwave frequency of 416 GHz ().
elements.clean_text:
Sign of D 

The positions of the resonance lines in EPR do not depend on the signs of the spin Hamiltonian parameters. However, the sign of D affects the intensity pattern in high-field EPR spectra at low temperatures. Using the intensity pattern to determine the sign of D in the antiferromagnetic dinuclear complexes is difficult; the overall spectra intensity decays to zero before the D effect can be seen in the powder spectra. Fortunately, single-crystal high-field EPR sometimes offers a solution. In this work, a 30 mg single crystal of [Cu2(μ-F)(μ-L m  *)2](BF4)3 (17) was grown and oriented in the HF EPR instrument with the y axis of the zfs tensor close to the direction of the magnetic field. The EPR spectra of sufficient quality could be recorded at 70 K with the microwave frequency of 416 GHz ().

elements.content: Single-crystal HF EPR spectra of [Cu2(μ-F)­(μ-L m *)2]­(BF4)3: blue, original experimental spectrum; red, integrated spectrum (absorption); olive, integrated absorption (intensity). The intensity ratio of the low-field line to the high-field line is 1.45.
elements.clean_text: 10  Single-crystal HF EPR spectra of [Cu2(μ-F)(μ-L m  *)2](BF4)3: blue, original experimental spectrum; red, integrated spectrum (absorption); olive, integrated absorption (intensity). The intensity ratio of the low-field line to the high-field line is 1.45.

elements.content: For a spin-triplet state, a pair of “allowed” transitions is observed at any orientation of a molecule versus the magnetic field. With the spin Hamiltonian parameters given in , at the Y orientation the lower-field transition should be more intense than the higher-field one if D is positive, which was indeed observed. The intensity ratio of the stronger to the weaker resonance in a pair R = ( e h ν / k T − 1 ) / ( 1 − e − h ν / k T ) is 1.33 at 70 K and 416 GHz, in a reasonable agreement with the experimental ratio of 1.45. That ratio is 1.008 for the X-band frequency at 70 K, explaining the need for the HF EPR. In this series of papers, we have only managed to determine the (positive) sign of D in a cyanido-bridged complex in which the isotropic exchange was much smaller than in the halogenido-bridged systems, enabling low-temperature (30 K) high-field EPR experiments on single crystals. This type of experiment cannot be repeated for the Cl–-bridged complexes, as the exchange interaction is much stronger, and the spectra cannot be observed at sufficiently low temperatures. We assume that D is positive also in the Cl–-bridged complexes.

elements.content: Further, we explored the zero-field splitting tensor in the Cl–- and F–-bridged compounds. To do so, it is more convenient to use the diagonal zero-field splitting tensor components D xx , etc., instead of the D and E parameters of the “giant spin” Hamiltonian (). The conversion is D xx = − D / 3 + E ⁣ D yy = − D / 3 − E ⁣ D z z = 2 D / 3 or in the opposite direction D = ( 2 D zz − D xx − D yy ) / 2 ⁣ E = ( D xx − D yy ) / 2 Both magnetic dipole–dipole interactions and the anisotropic exchange interactions contribute to the zero-field splitting tensor {D}: { D } = { D } dipole + { D } ex ­{D}ex can be calculated from the experimental D parameter by subtracting the dipolar contribution, which can be reasonably estimated from the structure. The details of such calculations are included in the SI, and the result applicable to both 7 and 8 is the set of diagonal {D}ex elements (D ex xx , D ex yy , D ex zz ) = (−0.1068 cm–1, –0.2323 cm–1, 0). When the same procedure is applied to [Cu2(μ-F)­(μ-L m *)2]­(BF4)3, one gets a set (−0.0443 cm–1, –0.2755 cm–1, 0).

elements.content: The exchange related contribution to zfs is caused by the mixing of the excited states of the dinuclear system to its ground state via the spin–orbit coupling. The appropriate excited states are such that one of the copper­(II) ions is in its ground state (d z 2 ) while the other copper­(II) is in one of the excited states ().

The exchange interactions in these pairs of orbitals contribute to the zero-field splitting tensor components D yy ex and D xx ex.

elements.content: The formulas for the D ex ii tensor components involve the same quantities λα2β2/ΔE(d z 2 , d n ) that appear in for g, as well as the exchange integrals J z 2 ,n between the ground state of one ion and excited states of another (see also ref where the exchange related zfs in the d x 2– y 2 case is discussed). These D ex ii tensor components can thus be expressed through the deviations of the g x and g y components from g of free electron, Δg x and Δg y (see also eq S3): D x x e x = − 1 24 ( Δ g x ) 2 J z 2 , y z D y y e x = − 1 24 ( Δ g y ) 2 J z 2 , x z D z z e x = 0 Note that the same sign convention is used as in and , −J z 2 ,n S 1 S 2, opposite to the convention used in ref . When applying , we obtained J(z 2, xz) = +60 cm–1 and J(z 2, yz) = +47 cm–1 for the F–-bridged case. For the linear Cl–-bridged complexes 7 and 8, we calculated J(z 2, xz) = +89 cm–1 and J(z 2, yz) = +79 cm–1. Because of the complicated way of obtaining these numbers, they are likely to have large error bars. Nevertheless, the positive (ferromagnetic) sign for J(z 2, xz) and J(z 2, yz) is expected as the interacting orbitals are orthogonal (i.e., do not overlap). The increase in the strength of these exchange interactions in the Cl–-bridged versus the F–-bridged complex may be due to the further penetration in space of the Cl– orbitals as compared to that of the F– orbitals. Finally, J(z 2, xz) and J(z 2, yz) found here appear to be of a reasonable order of magnitude when compared to those reported by others, although the system is very different. Table S5 shows that the values of 6λ/ΔE xz are not very different for the F–- and Cl–-bridged complexes. The reason for the improved “axiality” of the [Cu2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]3+ spectra versus [Cu2(μ-F)­(μ-L m *)2]3+ is the increased covalence of the d xz orbital (reduction of γ in and ) in [Cu2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]3+, which causes lowering of g y , according to . On the other hand, lower E in the Cl–-bridged complex compared to that for the F–-bridged complex appears to be caused by the J(z 2, xz) and J(z 2, yz) interaction magnitudes being closer to each other in the former.

shows that in zero field the observed spectra consist of quadrupole doublets that at 4.2 K are characterized by a quadrupole splitting ΔE Q = 3.942(3) and 3.662(4) mm/s and isomer shift δ = 1.068(3) and 1.155(3) mm/s for 1 and 16, respectively. These values are typical of high-spin iron­(II) ions. The observation of well-defined, symmetric quadrupole doublets with resonances that have a relatively narrow line width, Γ = 0.28(1) mm/s, indicates that, as expected, the two individual iron sites of the dimer cations are indistinguishable. The zero-field, temperature-dependent spectra recorded for these complexes showed that the quadrupole splitting is temperature independent. This observation indicates the presence for 1 and 16 of an isolated orbital ground state. The isomer shift values observed at room temperature are ∼0.15 mm/s smaller than those recorded at 4.2 K, a change that can be assigned to a typical second-order Doppler shift effect.

elements.content: For both iron complexes, the antiferromagnetic coupling between the local spins leads to the stabilization of a S t = 0 ground state. However, the difference in the magnitude of the exchange coupling causes different Mössbauer behavior. In 16, the lowest excited level, the |S t = 1, M S = 0⟩ spin substate of the triplet excited state is found to be only ∼2.7 cm–1 above the ground state, while for 1 this level is found ∼14 cm–1 above the ground state. Accordingly, the lowest excited state of 16 is thermally populated even at 4.2 K while for 1 at this temperature, regardless of the applied field, only the ground state is thermally populated. This observation is further corroborated by the observed magnetic hyperfine splitting. Thus, for 1 at 4.2 K, the applied field elicits a hyperfine splitting pattern that is essentially identical with that expected for a diamagnetic, S = 0 species, see . Comparison of the spectra recorded for 1 and 16 shows that this pattern is distinctly different for the two complexes. For 16, the sizable Boltzmann population of the lowest excited state leads to a substantial decrease in the magnitude of the observed magnetic hyperfine splitting. Regardless of the applied field, the spin expectation value of the ground state, |S t = 0, M S = 0⟩, is essentially null. In contrast, the lowest excited state, |S t = 1, M S = 0⟩, acquires a significant spin expectation value due to the mixing by the applied field of this state with the other two spin sublevels, |S t = 1, M S = ±1⟩, of the triplet spin state. The observed magnetic hyperfine splitting is proportional to the ⟨Ŝ⟩·Ã product where ⟨Ŝ⟩ is the spin expectation value and Ã the hyperfine coupling tensor. Since the spin expectation values can be easily calculated using , the simulations of the high-field, temperature-dependent spectra shown in red allowed us to determine hyperfine coupling tensor A as well as the asymmetry parameter of the electric field gradient η. These values are listed in and show that the spectra can be well-understood assuming axial A tensors for which the smallest component is found along the z axis.

elements.content: “Broken symmetry” density functional theory calculations were performed by using the software ORCA to rationalize the magnitudes of the exchange integrals. In this method, a self-consistent field (SCF) calculation is first performed for the maximum spin state of a dinuclear species. Next, a “broken symmetry” state is set up with the unpaired electrons being spin-up on one metal and spin-down on the other, and another SCF calculation is carried out. The energies of the high-spin and broken symmetry states are finally used to estimate the exchange integral value, – J (for Hamiltonian Ĥ = – J Ŝ 1 Ŝ 2), based on the equation −J = 2­(E HS – E HS)/(⟨S 2⟩HS – ⟨S 2⟩BS), where E HS and E BS are the energies of the high-spin (HS) and the broken symmetry (BS) states, and ⟨S 2⟩HS and ⟨S 2⟩BS are the expectation values of the spin-squared operator in the HS and BS states. Ahlrichs-type basis set TZVPP for the metal and all coordinated atoms and SVP for other atoms were used, combined with the B3LYP functional. Ahlrichs polarization functions from basis H-Kr and auxiliary bases from the TurboMole library were also used.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculation of the Exchange Integrals (-J)

"Broken symmetry" density functional theory calculations were performed by using the software ORCA to rationalize the magnitudes of the exchange integrals. In this method, a self-consistent field (SCF) calculation is first performed for the maximum spin state of a dinuclear species. Next, a "broken symmetry" state is set up with the unpaired electrons being spin-up on one metal and spin-down on the other, and another SCF calculation is carried out. The energies of the high-spin and broken symmetry states are finally used to estimate the exchange integral value, - J (for Hamiltonian Ĥ = - J Ŝ 1 Ŝ 2), based on the equation -J = 2(E HS - E HS)/(⟨S 2⟩HS - ⟨S 2⟩BS), where E HS and E BS are the energies of the high-spin (HS) and the broken symmetry (BS) states, and ⟨S 2⟩HS and ⟨S 2⟩BS are the expectation values of the spin-squared operator in the HS and BS states. Ahlrichs-type basis set TZVPP for the metal and all coordinated atoms and SVP for other atoms were used, combined with the B3LYP functional. Ahlrichs polarization functions from basis H-Kr and auxiliary bases from the TurboMole library were also used.

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction coordinates were used in the calculations. The molecules were simplified by removal of the phenylene rings as well as the methyl groups on the pyrazolyl fragments in L m * and placement of hydrogen atoms at appropriate positions. The J obtained from the formula converting the energy difference between the high-spin and the broken symmetry state used in this paper is referred to in the literature as “spin-projected” and should be appropriate for strong exchange interactions. The “non-spin-projected” formula results in a J that is 2 times smaller. In our recent papers we have always used the “spin-projected” J values, which were typically ∼30% larger than the experimental values. The “spin-projected” J values are shown in . presents the magnetic orbitals in the linear and bent copper­(II) complexes.

We synthesized a large family of monochloride-bridged metallacycles of the type [M2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L)2]3+ with ditopic, third-generation bis­(pyrazolyl)­methane ligands where L = L m , M = Cu­(II), Zn­(II), or L = L m *, M = Fe­(II), Co­(II), Ni­(II), Cu­(II), Zn­(II), Cd­(II). In addition, we successfully isolated [Cu2(μ-Br)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3·2CH3CN. The ESI+-MS of all of these complexes and NMR spectroscopy of the zinc­(II) and cadmium­(II) compounds clearly indicate the metallacyclic structure is stable in all phases.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

We synthesized a large family of monochloride-bridged metallacycles of the type [M2(μ-Cl)(μ-L)2]3+ with ditopic, third-generation bis(pyrazolyl)methane ligands where L = L   m  , M = Cu(II), Zn(II), or L = L   m  *, M = Fe(II), Co(II), Ni(II), Cu(II), Zn(II), Cd(II). In addition, we successfully isolated [Cu2(μ-Br)(μ-L   m  *)2](ClO4)3⋅2CH3CN. The ESI+-MS of all of these complexes and NMR spectroscopy of the zinc(II) and cadmium(II) compounds clearly indicate the metallacyclic structure is stable in all phases.

elements.content: To synthesize the chloride-bridged metallacycles we chose two distinct synthetic methods. The first is the direct reaction of the metallacycle building blocks, and the second is the reaction of the previously reported fluoride-bridged analogues with (CH3)3SiCl. The first method proved to be superior; the second method is successful only in one case for cobalt­(II) and two cases for copper­(II). We used the first method to isolate [Cu2(μ-Br)­(μ-L m *)2]­(ClO4)3·2CH3CN. Upon attempts to expand the bromide-bridged series to other metals, we isolated the nonmetallacyclic complex [Co2(μ-L m *)­Br4].
elements.clean_text: To synthesize the chloride-bridged metallacycles we chose two distinct synthetic methods. The first is the direct reaction of the metallacycle building blocks, and the second is the reaction of the previously reported fluoride-bridged analogues with (CH3)3SiCl. The first method proved to be superior; the second method is successful only in one case for cobalt(II) and two cases for copper(II). We used the first method to isolate [Cu2(μ-Br)(μ-L   m  *)2](ClO4)3⋅2CH3CN. Upon attempts to expand the bromide-bridged series to other metals, we isolated the nonmetallacyclic complex [Co2(μ-L   m  *)Br4].

elements.content: In all metallacyclic structures, the ligands L m or L m * adopt a syn-conformation, with both bis­(pyrazolyl)­methane units on the same side of the phenylene spacer. Crystallographic studies show that the 5-coordinate geometry around the metal centers is highly distorted, but it is closer to being trigonal bipyramidal than square pyramidal. For the copper­(II) compounds, as a result of the pseudo-Jahn–Teller distortion, the axial bond lengths are shorter than the equatorial ones, similarly to the fluoride- and hydroxide-bridged analogues. As observed with the fluoride and hydroxide analogues, the M–X–M angle in these complexes is either linear or very close to linear.
elements.clean_text: In all metallacyclic structures, the ligands L   m   or L   m  * adopt a syn-conformation, with both bis(pyrazolyl)methane units on the same side of the phenylene spacer. Crystallographic studies show that the 5-coordinate geometry around the metal centers is highly distorted, but it is closer to being trigonal bipyramidal than square pyramidal. For the copper(II) compounds, as a result of the pseudo-Jahn-Teller distortion, the axial bond lengths are shorter than the equatorial ones, similarly to the fluoride- and hydroxide-bridged analogues. As observed with the fluoride and hydroxide analogues, the M-X-M angle in these complexes is either linear or very close to linear.

elements.content: We now have enough data for copper­(II) to determine the impact of the two supporting ligands, L m and L m *, and the metallacyclic structure on the Cu–X bond distances. The L m * ligand has a moderating effect on the spread of the Cu–X bond lengths, . With this ligand, the average Cu–F (2.03 Å) and Cu–O­(H) (2.02 Å) bond lengths are slightly longer while the Cu–Cl (2.33 Å) and Cu–Br (2.47 Å) distances are shorter than predicted by the sum of the ionic radii of the corresponding ions (1.94, 1.97, 2.45, and 2.61 Å, respectively). In contrast to the longer than predicted Cu–F and Cu–OH distances in [Cu2(μ-X)­(μ-L m *)2]3+ complexes, in analogous L m compounds the Cu–X bond lengths (av Cu–F 1.95 Å and av Cu–OH 1.94 Å) are similar or slightly shorter than predicted. Interestingly, the average Cu–Cl bond length in [Cu2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m )2]3+ is 2.32 Å, shorter than predicted, 2.45 Å, and virtually the same as that for [Cu2(μ-Cl)­(μ-L m *)2]3+. Thus, for the small bridging anions F– and OH–, the size of the “pocket” generated by the metallacycle [Cu2(μ-L m )2]4+ is just about the correct size, but the steric effects created by the addition of the methyl groups in L m * enforce longer Cu–X distances. For the bigger anions, Cl– and Br–, the “natural pocket” generated by the metallacycle is smaller for both ligands causing mild compression of the M–X distances. For these larger X– groups, the steric interactions introduced by the bulkier L m * ligand are not important.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility data for the Cl–- and Br–-bridged copper­(II) metallacycles showed strong antiferromagnetic interactions, see . The magnitude of the −J values is particularly surprising given that the geometry of these complexes has the interaction being transmitted through overlap of the “doughnut” portion of the magnetic d z 2 orbital with the bridging halide s and p x orbitals. Large −J values have been observed previously when a bridging group with relatively large Cu–X–Cu angles overlaps with the magnetic d x 2 –y 2 orbital in square planar or pyramidal geometry or along the z axis of a trigonal bipyramid. For the one known complex with a linear Cl– bridge, a bridge oriented similarly to those reported here, [Cu2(tet-b)2Cl]­(ClO4)3, the −J value was reported to be 288 cm–1. This value is substantially smaller than the 720 cm–1 value observed for linearly bridged 7, or even the 540 cm–1 value for 9·xCH3CN, where the weighted average Cu–X–Cu angle is 154.5°. The bromide-bridged compound 14·2CH3CN exhibits one of the strongest antiferromagnetic interactions observed in a dinuclear compound, with −J = 945 cm–1; only a couple of other compounds have −J above 1000 cm–1.

The magnitude of the -J values is particularly surprising given that the geometry of these complexes has the interaction being transmitted through overlap of the "doughnut" portion of the magnetic d z 2  orbital with the bridging halide s and p x  orbitals. Large -J values have been observed previously when a bridging group with relatively large Cu-X-Cu angles overlaps with the magnetic d x 2  -y 2  orbital in square planar or pyramidal geometry or along the z axis of a trigonal bipyramid. For the one known complex with a linear Cl- bridge, a bridge oriented similarly to those reported here, [Cu2(tet-b)2Cl](ClO4)3, the -J value was reported to be 288 cm-1. This value is substantially smaller than the 720 cm-1 value observed for linearly bridged 7, or even the 540 cm-1 value for 9⋅xCH3CN, where the weighted average Cu-X-Cu angle is 154.5°. The bromide-bridged compound 14⋅2CH3CN exhibits one of the strongest antiferromagnetic interactions observed in a dinuclear compound, with -J = 945 cm-1; only a couple of other compounds have -J above 1000 cm-1.

elements.content: The larger size of Cl– and Br– as well as the resulting compression of the metallacyclic pockets, , are likely the main reasons for the increasing strength of the antiferromagnetic interactions in comparison to analogous F–-bridged compounds, by increasing the overlap between the magnetic orbitals and the delocalization of unpaired spins toward the bridging halides. On the basis of the structure of the [Cu2(μ-X)­(μ-L m *)2]3+ series, X = F–, Cl–, OH–, Br–, where the overall metallacyclic structures are very similar and the Cu–X–Cu angle is fixed at 180°, the following trends have been established: the strengths of the antiferromagnetic superexchange interactions increase in the sequence F– (−J = 340 cm–1) < Cl– (−J = 720 cm–1) < OH– (−J = 808 cm–1) < Br– (−J = 945 cm–1), where for Br–, and even OH–, the interaction is so strong that the magnetic moment is close to zero even at room temperature. These data represent the first series of complexes where this trend has been definitively established. It is particularly interesting that the exchange coupling is so much stronger in the OH–-bridged compared to the F–-bridged complexes given that the size of the bridging group is so similar. The oxygen atomic orbitals are higher in energy than the fluorine atomic orbitals and therefore closer in energy to the atomic orbitals of copper­(II). This improved energy matching should result in stronger covalency of the Cu–O bonds compared to that of the Cu–F bonds. This explanation appears to be confirmed by the DFT calculations that show substantially higher unpaired electron density of 0.136 on the bridging O– ion than 0.072 on the F– ion (Table S4 in ref ). In the Cl–-bridged complex 7, the total unpaired electron density on the Cl– ion is 0.101, and in the Br–-bridged complex 14 it is 0.120. Thus, increased covalency resulting from better energy matching of the orbitals for these two halides also explains the increasing −J values.

elements.content: Bending the bridge from linearity in these complexes causes reduction of the magnetic orbital overlap, which leads to a weaker exchange coupling ( and ). Also, the unpaired electron densities on the two equatorial nitrogen donor atoms become more diverse than in the linearly bridged compounds. A similar and even stronger effect was observed in our bent OH–-bridged system where the equatorial N atom with reduced electron density also moved away from the copper­(II) ion to become an axial ligand in the square pyramidal coordination. In this OH– case, a change in the g pattern was observed, which is consistent with the change of the ground state from d z 2 in the linear complex to d x 2–y 2 in the bent one. However, complex 9, a mixture of two bent species, still exhibits a g pattern consistent with a d z 2 ground state.

In this OH- case, a change in the g pattern was observed, which is consistent with the change of the ground state from d z 2  in the linear complex to d x 2-y 2  in the bent one. However, complex 9, a mixture of two bent species, still exhibits a g pattern consistent with a d z 2  ground state.

elements.content: In our previous works with F–-bridged complexes, we have shown that the exchange constant −J decreases in the sequence Cu2+ > Ni2+ > Co2+ > Fe2+ > Mn2+. The present results confirm these trends, . The change of F– by Cl– in the bridge causes −J to increase for the Fe­(II), Ni­(II), and Co­(II) complexes, as discussed above for the copper­(II) complexes, and the Cu2+ > Ni2+ > Co2+ > Fe2+ trend across the periodic table is maintained. The “broken symmetry” DFT calculations reproduce all of these trends ().
elements.clean_text: In our previous works with F--bridged complexes, we have shown that the exchange constant -J decreases in the sequence Cu2+ > Ni2+ > Co2+ > Fe2+ > Mn2+. The present results confirm these trends, . The change of F- by Cl- in the bridge causes -J to increase for the Fe(II), Ni(II), and Co(II) complexes, as discussed above for the copper(II) complexes, and the Cu2+ > Ni2+ > Co2+ > Fe2+ trend across the periodic table is maintained. The "broken symmetry" DFT calculations reproduce all of these trends ().

When comparing the J magnitudes for complexes of different metals, it is important to note that they depend on the number of unpaired electrons. According to ref , the contribution to the antiferromagnetic interactions due to various pairs of magnetic orbitals is J = − 2 n 2 ∑ i | Δ i S i | where n is the number of unpaired electrons on a metal ion, Δ i is the difference between the energies of the antisymmetric and symmetric combinations of the magnetic orbitals in pair “i”, and Si is the overlap integral of these magnetic orbitals. For a meaningful comparison of the exchange constants for dinuclear complexes of different metals, J should be multiplied by n 2. For the Cl–-bridged complexes (), this procedure yields 720, 392, 486, and 544 cm–1 for the Cu2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Fe2+ complexes, respectively. These numbers are now similar and show that one pair of magnetic orbitals in the copper­(II) system is more efficient in transmitting the exchange interactions than are a few such pairs in other metal complexes.

For the Cl--bridged complexes (), this procedure yields 720, 392, 486, and 544 cm-1 for the Cu2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Fe2+ complexes, respectively. elements.content: We have now been able to record EPR data on a variety of monoanionic bridged dinuclear copper­(II) complexes. This extensive data is unique for a series for complexes where the geometry of the system is tightly controlled. Despite much stronger antiferromagnetic interaction in our Cl–-bridged copper­(II) complexes, compared to the F–-bridged ones, the Cl–-bridged species produced much better EPR spectra. Contrary to popular belief, the depopulation of the triplet state is not the main reason for problems in recording EPR of dinuclear compounds. Even with −J = 720 cm–1 (in 7), the triplet state population at 300 K is still 0.087 (and 0.37 for −J = 340 cm–1 in the F–-bridged species). The real problem is the fast relaxation at higher temperatures resulting in increased line width. An EPR spectroscopist tends to record spectra at low temperatures to improve their quality, but there is no such option in the case of systems as strongly antiferromagnetic as ours. The three g components in 7, 8, and 9 are very different from each other, and the smallest one equals 2.000 ( and Figure S13), indicating that the unpaired electron on each copper­(II) center is located on an orbital with predominantly d z 2 character. This result is also found for the Br–-bridged complex 14, in which the g parameters could not be determined as accurately as for the other copper­(II) complexes due to the low quality of its EPR spectra (only Q-band, HF spectra could not be observed).
elements.clean_text: We have now been able to record EPR data on a variety of monoanionic bridged dinuclear copper(II) complexes. This extensive data is unique for a series for complexes where the geometry of the system is tightly controlled. Despite much stronger antiferromagnetic interaction in our Cl--bridged copper(II) complexes, compared to the F--bridged ones, the Cl--bridged species produced much better EPR spectra. Contrary to popular belief, the depopulation of the triplet state is not the main reason for problems in recording EPR of dinuclear compounds. Even with -J = 720 cm-1 (in 7), the triplet state population at 300 K is still 0.087 (and 0.37 for -J = 340 cm-1 in the F--bridged species). The real problem is the fast relaxation at higher temperatures resulting in increased line width. An EPR spectroscopist tends to record spectra at low temperatures to improve their quality, but there is no such option in the case of systems as strongly antiferromagnetic as ours. The three g components in 7, 8, and 9 are very different from each other, and the smallest one equals 2.000 ( and Figure S13), indicating that the unpaired electron on each copper(II) center is located on an orbital with predominantly d z 2  character. This result is also found for the Br--bridged complex 14, in which the g parameters could not be determined as accurately as for the other copper(II) complexes due to the low quality of its EPR spectra (only Q-band, HF spectra could not be observed).

elements.content: In the case of the F–-bridged copper­(II) complex [Cu2(μ-F)­(μ-L m *)2]­(BF4)3, we were able for the first time in this series of compounds to determine the positive sign of the D parameter. This sign is important when calculating the anisotropic exchange contribution to D and E parameters, and it helped in proving the (expected) ferromagnetic character of the J(z 2, xz) and J(z 2, yz) interactions. Positive D was also previously found in the analogous CN–-bridged complex. Although the sign of D was impossible to determine in the Cl–-, OH–-, and Br–-bridged systems because of the extremely strong antiferromagnetism, there is no reason to expect it to be different than that in the F–-bridged complex.

This sign is important when calculating the anisotropic exchange contribution to D and E parameters, and it helped in proving the (expected) ferromagnetic character of the J(z 2, xz) and J(z 2, yz) interactions. Positive D was also previously found in the analogous CN--bridged complex. Although the sign of D was impossible to determine in the Cl--, OH--, and Br--bridged systems because of the extremely strong antiferromagnetism, there is no reason to expect it to be different than that in the F--bridged complex.

elements.content: Analysis of the zero-field Mössbauer spectra recorded for 1 and 16 demonstrates the presence for these complexes of two identical high-spin iron­(II) sites. While the ground spin state for 1 is essentially isolated, the lowest excited S = 1 spin state for 16 exhibits a sizable Boltzmann population, even at 4.2 K.

While the ground spin state for 1 is essentially isolated, the lowest excited S = 1 spin state for 16 exhibits a sizable Boltzmann population, even at 4.2 K.

elements.content: In this project, we have used two third-generation, ditopic bis­(pyrazolyl)­methane ligands (L) to synthesize and study an unprecedented series of linear or nearly linear, monobridged dinuclear metallacycles of the formula [M2(μ-X)­(μ-L)2]3+, where X = F–, Cl–, Br–, OH–, CN–, N3 –, and M = Mn­(II), Fe­(II), Co­(II), Ni­(II), Cu­(II), Zn­(II), and Cd­(II). In the extensive series of monobridged, metal­(II) halide- and hydroxide-bridged compounds, the strength of the superexchange interactions depend on the electronic nature of the bridge and the bridging angle. The size of the metallacyclic pocket and its influence on the M–X distances are also factors to be considered. The antiferromagnetic interactions increase in the halide complexes with increasing size of the halide; however, size is not the only factor, as the hydroxide complexes show stronger interactions than the chlorides reported here. Decreasing the bridge angle lowers the antiferromagnetic interactions. Antiferromagnetic interactions also dramatically decrease when one moves from metal complexes of copper­(II) to the left across the first row transition metals. For the new complexes reported here, EPR spectra have confirmed the d z 2 ground state of copper­(II), a result supported by DFT calculations. Determination of the sign of D in two of the copper­(II) complexes and estimation of the anisotropic exchange related contribution to the zero-field splitting are important and unique results. Solution NMR data reported here and in the previous papers demonstrate that the metallacyclic structure is retained in solution, and measured −J values in solution for the copper­(II) complexes are slightly lower but parallel those measured in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this project, we have used two third-generation, ditopic bis(pyrazolyl)methane ligands (L) to synthesize and study an unprecedented series of linear or nearly linear, monobridged dinuclear metallacycles of the formula [M2(μ-X)(μ-L)2]3+, where X = F-, Cl-, Br-, OH-, CN-, N3 -, and M = Mn(II), Fe(II), Co(II), Ni(II), Cu(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II). In the extensive series of monobridged, metal(II) halide- and hydroxide-bridged compounds, the strength of the superexchange interactions depend on the electronic nature of the bridge and the bridging angle. The size of the metallacyclic pocket and its influence on the M-X distances are also factors to be considered. The antiferromagnetic interactions increase in the halide complexes with increasing size of the halide; however, size is not the only factor, as the hydroxide complexes show stronger interactions than the chlorides reported here. Decreasing the bridge angle lowers the antiferromagnetic interactions. Antiferromagnetic interactions also dramatically decrease when one moves from metal complexes of copper(II) to the left across the first row transition metals. For the new complexes reported here, EPR spectra have confirmed the d z 2  ground state of copper(II), a result supported by DFT calculations. Determination of the sign of D in two of the copper(II) complexes and estimation of the anisotropic exchange related contribution to the zero-field splitting are important and unique results. Solution NMR data reported here and in the previous papers demonstrate that the metallacyclic structure is retained in solution, and measured -J values in solution for the copper(II) complexes are slightly lower but parallel those measured in the solid state.

  Caution! Although no problems were encountered during this work with the perchlorate salts, these compounds should be considered potentially explosive!  

[Fe2(μ-Cl)(μ-L m  *)2](ClO4)3, 1 

The iron(II) compounds, Fe(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.183 g, 0.504 mmol) and FeCl2 (0.022 g, 0.17 mmol), were dissolved in 4 mL of methanol. Separately, L   m   * (0.324 g, 0.672 mmol) was dissolved in 12 mL of methanol and was transferred by cannula into the iron(II) solution. The reaction mixture was stirred for 5 h, after which time the system was filtered by cannula; the remaining solid was washed with Et2O (10 mL) and dried under vacuum overnight, affording 0.200 g (42%) of the crude product. Single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray and other studies were grown by the vapor diffusion of Et2O into 1 mL of acetonitrile solutions of the crude solid. Anal. Calcd (Found) for C56H68Cl4Fe2N16O12: C, 47.68 (47.98); H, 4.86 (4.88); N, 15.89 (16.27). Under N2, [Co2(μ-F)(μ-L   m  *)2](BF4)3 (0.166 g, 0.121 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of dry acetonitrile and cooled to 0 °C for 30 min. Solid (CH3)3SiCl (0.013 g, 0.12 mmol) was added all at once to the cobalt(II) solution. The solution immediately changed color from pink to blue. The reaction flask was removed from the cooling bath, allowed to warm to room temperature, and stirred for 12 h. The solvent was removed by rotary evaporation, and the product was recrystallized by vapor diffusion of Et2O into 1 mL acetonitrile solutions of the blue solid. The resulting pink crystals were identified as 3, 0.050 g (30%). Anal. Calcd (Found) for C56H68ClCo2N16B3F12: C, 48.78 (48.20); H, 4.97 (4.57); N, 16.25 (16.17). From the same vapor diffusion tubes that contain 3, blue crystals of [Co2(μ-L   m  *)Cl4], 4, were also isolated. The two types of crystals were hand separated. MS ESI(+) m/z (rel % abund) [assgn]: 705 (8) [Co2(L   m  *)Cl3]+, 602 (9) [Co2(L   m  *)2Cl(BF4)]2+, 483 [L   m  * + H]+, 372 (100) [Co2(L   m  *)2Cl]3+.
